items.title: Syrian Refugees Strain Resources in Jordan
items.abstract: Despite plans by aid organizations to help at least 50,000 urban refugees, a large number will be left out because of the rising numbers of Syrians fleeing across the border each day.
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: Charting a Post-Pollution Path for Cities – From London, 1952, through Beijing, 2013
items.abstract: Facing epic smog, China charts a shift from coal to gas for Beijing, and beyond.

items.title: Company Defrauded City in Water Plant Work, Contractor Says
items.abstract: At a Bronx plant that has been plagued by problems, a firm is said to have evaded requirements on oversight by an electrician and on hiring companies owned by women or minorities.

items.title: Rendering a City With a Blowtorch
items.abstract: Belarus Free Theater offers a scathing mosaic of its home city with “Minsk, 2011,” at the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater.

items.title: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
items.abstract: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

items.title: A Boutique for the Great Outdoors and the Urban Wild
items.abstract: Snow Peak, newly opened in Manhattan, is more than a camping store.

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: Michigan’s Failure to Protect Flint
items.abstract: The state, which had played down findings of high levels of lead in the city’s water, must step in to find solutions.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: This Is Probably the Best Bath in New York City
items.abstract: For $7,000, you too can bathe like a very wealthy person.

items.title: What’s Coming in New York Real Estate in 2019
items.abstract: An already soft market will get another 20,000 new apartments, making it an even stronger buyer’s and renter’s market.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.
